subject: Re: Using JUnit for Performance Tests?

messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Robert Bateman <rbatemanmi@y...> wrote:

> I've found the JUnit task of ANT to be extremely good. It provides
> timings of the executed function and everything.

That just tells you how long it took to run. It doesn't help with
performance tests. For that you want to be able to create a test that
asserts that a specific operation does not take longer than a
particular amount of time. This is for cases where a certain level of
performance is a requirement. By having a test for it you a) know
when your optimization has been successfull and so avoid unnecessary
optimization, and b) know when things slow down for some reason.

> Being new at JUnit, the timing tests are what alerted me to the fact
> that JUnit reloads stuff before each test (something I didn't know
> before I found the ANT task.)

Yes, that's critical to understand for a variety of reasons. A new
instance of your TestCase is created for every test method that is
run, setup called, the test method called, and teardown called.
That's the key to keeping them isolated and independant.

Dave
